[MS. Trin. Coll. Camb., R. 3. 20, 71â74.] Nowe foloweÃ¾e nexst Ã¾e devyse of a momyng to fore Ã¾e Kyng Henry Ã¾e Sixst, being in his Castell of Wyndesore, Ã¾e fest of his Crystmasse holding Ã¾er, made by Lidegate daun Iohn, Ã¾e Munk of Bury; howe Ã¾ampull and Ã¾e floure delys came first to Ã¾e kynges of Fraunce by myrakle at Reynes. 1 Mooste noble Prynce of Cristen prynces alle, To Youre Hyeghnesse lat hit beo plesaunce, In youre presence men may to mynde calle, Howe Ã¾at whylom oure worthy reavme of Fraunce Conuerted was frome Ã¾eyre mescreaunce, Whane Ã¾e Lord of Lordes caste a sight Vpon youre lande and made His grace alight. 2 For in Ã¾e heghe, hevenly consistorye, Be ful acorde of Ã¾e Trynitee, As in cronycles maked is memorye, Ãe Lord, which is called oon, twoo and thre, His eyeghe of mercy caste on Cloudovee, Shadde His grace of goostely influence Towardes Ã¾at kyng, having his aduertence, 3 Ãat he shoulde passe frome paganymes lawe By prescyence, which Ã¾at is devyne, His hert al hoolly and him self withdrowe Frome his ydooles, and alle hees rytes fyne, Whane hevenly grace did vpon him shyne, By meene oonly and by devoute preyer Of Saint Cloote, moost goodly and entier. 4 Hir hertely loue, hir meditacyouns, Hir wacche, hir fasting and hir parfyt lyf, Hir stedfast hoope, hir hooly orysouns, Hir conuersacyoun moost contemplatyff Stynt in Fraunce of Mawmetrye Ã¾e stryff, Causing Ã¾e lawe, moost souerein of vertue To sprede abroode of oure Lord Ihesu. 5 Hir meryte caused and hir parfit entent, Ãat Crystes feyth aboute Ã¾er did sprede, Whane Ã¾at an aungel was frome heven sent Vn to an hermyte, of parfyt lyf in deed, Presented it, whoo-so can take heed; A shelde of azure, moost souerein by devys, And in Ã¾e feelde of golde three floure delys. 6 At Ioye en Vale, with-oute more obstacle, Fel al Ã¾is cas, where Ã¾aungel doune alight, A place notable, chosen by myracle, Which thorughe al Fraunce shadde his bemys light. God of his grace caste on Ã¾at place a sight, For to Ã¾at reavme in passing avauntage In Ã¾ilke vale was sette Ã¾at hermytage. 7 Al Ã¾is came in, whoo-so list to seen, I dare afferme it with-oute any dreed, By parfytnesse of Ã¾e hooly qweene, Saynte Cloote, floure of wommanheed. What euer she spake, acordant was Ã¾e deed: I mene it Ã¾us, Ã¾at worde and werke were oon; It is no wonder, for wymmen soo beon echoon. A daun Iohan, est y vray? 8 Hir hoolynesse Fraunce did enlumyne And Crystes fayth gretly magnefye. Loo what grace dooÃ¾e in wymmen shyne, Whas assuraunce noman may denye. To seye pleyne trouth nys no flaterye; But stabulnesse in wymmen for to fynde, DeemeÃ¾e youre selff wher it komeÃ¾e hem of kynde. 9 For thorughe meeknesse, yif it be aduerted, Of Saynte Cloote, and thorugh hir hyeghe prudence, Kyng Cloudovee was to oure feyth conuerted. In hir Ã¾er was so entier diligence, Fully devoyde of slouthe and necglygence, Ne stynt nought, til Ã¾at hir lord haÃ¾e take Ãe feyth of Cryst and his errour forsake. 10 Ãis made, Ã¾e kyng Ã¾at Crystes feyth tooke, For he was booÃ¾e manly and rightwys, Ãe three crepaudes Ã¾is noble kyng forsooke, And in his sheelde he bare thre floure delys, Sent frome heven, a tresore of gret prys; Affter at Reynes, Ã¾e story telleÃ¾e Ã¾us, Baptysed lowly of Saint Remigius. 11 Ãampolle of golde a colver brought adovne, With which he was, Ã¾is hooly kyng, ennoynt. Gret prees Ã¾er was stonding envyroun, For to beholde Ã¾e kyng frome poynt to poynt. For where as he stoode, in gret desioynt, First a paynyme, by baptyme anoon right Was so conuerted, and bekame Crystes knight. 12 At Reynes yit Ã¾at hooly vnccyoun Conserued is for a remembraunce, And of coustume, by reuolucyoun Of God provyded, with due observaunce, Tannoynte of coustume kynges wheeche in Fraunce Ioustely succeede, Ã¾e story dooÃ¾e vs leere; Of which Sixst Henry, Ã¾at nowe sitteÃ¾e here, 13 Right soone shal, with Goddes hooly grace, As he is borne by successyoun, Be weel resceyued in Ã¾e same place And by vertu of Ã¾at vnccyoun Atteyne in knighthoode vn-to ful hye renoun, Resceyve his coroune, he and his successours, By tytle of right, lyche hees progenytours. 14 Nowe, Royal Braunche, O Blood of Saint Lowys, So lyke it nowe to Ãy Magnyfycence, Ãat Ã¾e story of Ã¾e flour delys May here be shewed in Ã¾yne heghe presence, And Ã¾at Ã¾y noble, royal Excellence Lyst to supporte, here sitting in Ã¾y see, Right as it fell Ã¾is myracle to see.
